notes.text:
An update for kernel-rt is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 8.

Red Hat Product Security has rated this update as having a security impact of Important. A Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) base score, which gives a detailed severity rating, is available for each vulnerability from the CVE link(s) in the References section.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The kernel-rt packages provide the Real Time Linux Kernel, which enables fine-tuning for systems with extremely high determinism requirements.

Security Fix(es):

* kernel: use after free in unix_stream_sendpage (CVE-2023-4622)

* kernel: vmwgfx: reference count issue leads to use-after-free in surface handling (CVE-2023-5633)

* kernel: netfilter: potential slab-out-of-bound access due to integer underflow (CVE-2023-42753)

* Kernel: UAF during login when accessing the shost ipaddress (CVE-2023-2162)

* hw amd: Return Address Predictor vulnerability leading to information disclosure (CVE-2023-20569)

For more details about the security issue(s), including the impact, a CVSS score, acknowledgments, and other related information, refer to the CVE page(s) listed in the References section.

Bug Fix(es):

* kernel-rt: update RT source tree to the latest RHEL-8.9.z1 Batch (JIRA:RHEL-17347)
notes.title: Details

notes.text: An integer overflow was found in the Linux kernel's vmwgfx driver. This flaw allows a local, unprivileged attacker with access to either /dev/dri/card0 or /dev/dri/rendererD128, and able to issue an ioctl() on the resulting file descriptor to crash the system, causing a denial of service.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: vmwgfx: integer overflow in vmwgfx_execbuf.c
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: Systems making use of the vmwgfx driver are potentially affected by this flaw; systems without the vmwgfx driver loaded are not affected by this flaw.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

To mitigate this issue, it is possible to prevent the affected code from being loaded by blacklisting the vmwgfx kernel module. For instructions relating to blacklisting a kernel module, please see https://access.redhat.com/solutions/41278.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: vmwgfx: integer overflow in vmwgfx_execbuf.c

notes.text: A use-after-free flaw was found in iscsi_sw_tcp_session_create in drivers/scsi/iscsi_tcp.c in the SCSI sub-component in the Linux Kernel. This issue could allow an attacker to leak kernel internal information.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: UAF during login when accessing the shost ipaddress
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

This flaw can be mitigated by preventing the affected iscsi_tcp.ko kernel module from loading during the boot time, ensure the module is added into the blacklist file.
~~~
Refer:  
How do I blacklist a kernel module to prevent it from loading automatically? 
https://access.redhat.com/solutions/41278
~~~

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: UAF during login when accessing the shost ipaddress

notes.text: A use-after-free flaw was found in the Linux kernel's af_unix component that allows local privilege escalation. The unix_stream_sendpage() function tries to add data to the last skb in the peer's recv queue without locking the queue. This issue leads to a race condition where the unix_stream_sendpage() function could access a skb that is being released by garbage collection, resulting in a use-after-free issue.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: use after free in unix_stream_sendpage
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation for this issue is either not available or currently available options don't meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: use after free in unix_stream_sendpage

notes.text: The reference count changes made as part of the CVE-2023-33951 and CVE-2023-33952 fixes exposed a use-after-free flaw in the way memory objects were handled when they were being used to store a surface. When running inside a VMware guest with 3D acceleration enabled, a local, unprivileged user could potentially use this flaw to escalate their privileges.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: vmwgfx: reference count issue leads to use-after-free in surface handling
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

This flaw can be mitigated by turning off 3D acceleration in VMware (if possible) or preventing the affected `vmwgfx` kernel module from being loaded. For instructions on how to blacklist a kernel module, please see https://access.redhat.com/solutions/41278.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: vmwgfx: reference count issue leads to use-after-free in surface handling

notes.text: A side channel vulnerability was found in hw amd. Some AMD CPUs may allow an attacker to influence the return address prediction. This issue may result in speculative execution at an attacker-controlled instruction pointer register, potentially leading to information disclosure.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: amd: Return Address Predictor vulnerability leading to information disclosure
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.

Mitigation, other than installed the updated packages, for this issue is either not available or the currently available options don't meet the Red Hat Product Security criteria comprising ease of use and deployment, applicability to widespread installation base or stability.

vulnerabilities.title: amd: Return Address Predictor vulnerability leading to information disclosure

notes.text: An array indexing vulnerability was found in the netfilter subsystem of the Linux kernel. A missing macro could lead to a miscalculation of the `h->nets` array offset, providing attackers with the primitive to arbitrarily increment/decrement a memory buffer out-of-bound. This issue may allow a local user to crash the system or potentially escalate their privileges on the system.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: kernel: netfilter: potential slab-out-of-bound access due to integer underflow
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

The system must be rebooted for this update to take effect.
Red Hat has investigated whether a possible mitigation exists for this issue, and has not been able to identify a practical example. Please update the affected package as soon as possible.

vulnerabilities.title: kernel: netfilter: potential slab-out-of-bound access due to integer underflow
